  <div id="sidebar-toggle"></div>
  <div id="container">
    <div class="docs markdown"><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tailwindlabs/prettier-plugin-tailwindcss/main/.github/banner.jpg" alt="prettier-plugin-tailwindcss" />
<p>A <a href="https://prettier.io/">Prettier v3+</a> plugin for Tailwind CSS v3.0+ that automatically sorts classes based on <a href="https://tailwindcss.com/blog/automatic-class-sorting-with-prettier#how-classes-are-sorted">our recommended class order</a>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="installation">
  <h2>
    <a href="#installation" name="installation" class="pilcrow"></a>
Installation
  </h2>
</div>
<p>To get started, install <code>prettier-plugin-tailwindcss</code> as a dev-dependency:</p>
<pre><code class="sh">npm install -D prettier prettier-plugin-tailwindcss
</code></pre>
<p>Then add the plugin to your <a href="https://prettier.io/docs/en/configuration.html">Prettier configuration</a>:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;plugins&quot;: [&quot;prettier-plugin-tailwindcss&quot;]
}
</code></pre>
<p>When using a JavaScript config, you can import the types for IntelliSense:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// prettier.config.js</span>

<span class="hljs-comment">/** <span class="hljs-doctag">@type <span class="hljs-type">{import('prettier').Config &amp; import('prettier-plugin-tailwindcss').PluginOptions}</span> </span>*/</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> {
  <span class="hljs-attr">plugins</span>: [<span class="hljs-string">"prettier-plugin-tailwindcss"</span>],
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="upgrading-to-v0.5.x">
  <h2>
    <a href="#upgrading-to-v0.5.x" name="upgrading-to-v0.5.x" class="pilcrow"></a>
Upgrading to v0.5.x
  </h2>
</div>
<p>As of v0.5.x, this plugin now requires Prettier v3 and is ESM-only. This means it cannot be loaded via <code>require()</code>. For more information see our <a href="https://github.com/tailwindlabs/prettier-plugin-tailwindcss/issues/207#issuecomment-1698071122">upgrade guide</a>.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="options">
  <h2>
    <a href="#options" name="options" class="pilcrow"></a>
Options
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="specifying-your-tailwind-stylesheet-path-tailwind-css-v4+">
  <h3>
    <a href="#specifying-your-tailwind-stylesheet-path-tailwind-css-v4+" name="specifying-your-tailwind-stylesheet-path-tailwind-css-v4+" class="pilcrow"></a>
Specifying your Tailwind stylesheet path (Tailwind CSS v4+)
  </h3>
</div>
<p>When using Tailwind CSS v4 you must specify your CSS file entry point, which includes your theme, custom utilities, and other Tailwind configuration options. To do this, use the <code>tailwindStylesheet</code> option in your Prettier configuration.</p>
<p>Note that paths are resolved relative to the Prettier configuration file.</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindStylesheet&quot;: &quot;./resources/css/app.css&quot;
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="specifying-your-tailwind-javascript-config-path-tailwind-css-v3">
  <h3>
    <a href="#specifying-your-tailwind-javascript-config-path-tailwind-css-v3" name="specifying-your-tailwind-javascript-config-path-tailwind-css-v3" class="pilcrow"></a>
Specifying your Tailwind JavaScript config path (Tailwind CSS v3)
  </h3>
</div>
<p>To ensure that the class sorting takes into consideration any of your project's Tailwind customizations, it needs access to your <a href="https://tailwindcss.com/docs/configuration">Tailwind configuration file</a> (<code>tailwind.config.js</code>).</p>
<p>By default the plugin will look for this file in the same directory as your Prettier configuration file. However, if your Tailwind configuration is somewhere else, you can specify this using the <code>tailwindConfig</code> option in your Prettier configuration.</p>
<p>Note that paths are resolved relative to the Prettier configuration file.</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindConfig&quot;: &quot;./styles/tailwind.config.js&quot;
}
</code></pre>
<p>If a local configuration file cannot be found the plugin will fallback to the default Tailwind configuration.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="sorting-non-standard-attributes">
  <h2>
    <a href="#sorting-non-standard-attributes" name="sorting-non-standard-attributes" class="pilcrow"></a>
Sorting non-standard attributes
  </h2>
</div>
<p>By default this plugin sorts classes in the <code>class</code> attribute, any framework-specific equivalents like <code>className</code>, <code>:class</code>, <code>[ngClass]</code>, and any Tailwind <code>@apply</code> directives.</p>
<p>You can sort additional attributes using the <code>tailwindAttributes</code> option, which takes an array of attribute names:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindAttributes&quot;: [&quot;myClassList&quot;]
}
</code></pre>
<p>With this configuration, any classes found in the <code>myClassList</code> attribute will be sorted:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyButton</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span> <span class="hljs-attr">myClassList</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"rounded bg-blue-500 px-4 py-2 text-base text-white"</span>&gt;</span>
      {children}
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span></span>
  );
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="using-regex-patterns">
  <h3>
    <a href="#using-regex-patterns" name="using-regex-patterns" class="pilcrow"></a>
Using regex patterns
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You can also use regular expressions to match multiple attributes. Patterns should be enclosed in forward slashes. Note that JS regex literals are not supported with Prettier:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindAttributes&quot;: [&quot;myClassList&quot;, &quot;/data-.*/&quot;]
}
</code></pre>
<p>This example will sort classes in the <code>myClassList</code> attribute as well as any attribute starting with <code>data-</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyButton</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span>
      <span class="hljs-attr">myClassList</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"rounded bg-blue-500 px-4 py-2 text-base text-white"</span>
      <span class="hljs-attr">data-theme</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"dark:bg-gray-800 bg-white"</span>
      <span class="hljs-attr">data-classes</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"flex items-center"</span>
    &gt;</span>
      {children}
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span></span>
  );
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="sorting-classes-in-function-calls">
  <h2>
    <a href="#sorting-classes-in-function-calls" name="sorting-classes-in-function-calls" class="pilcrow"></a>
Sorting classes in function calls
  </h2>
</div>
<p>In addition to sorting classes in attributes, you can also sort classes in strings provided to function calls. This is useful when working with libraries like <a href="https://github.com/lukeed/clsx">clsx</a> or <a href="https://cva.style/">cva</a>.</p>
<p>You can sort classes in function calls using the <code>tailwindFunctions</code> option, which takes a list of function names:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindFunctions&quot;: [&quot;clsx&quot;]
}
</code></pre>
<p>With this configuration, any classes in <code>clsx()</code> function calls will be sorted:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> clsx <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'clsx'</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyButton</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ isHovering, children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">let</span> classes = clsx(
    <span class="hljs-string">'rounded bg-blue-500 px-4 py-2 text-base text-white'</span>,
    {
      <span class="hljs-string">'bg-blue-700 text-gray-100'</span>: isHovering,
    },
  )

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span> <span class="hljs-attr">className</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{classes}</span>&gt;</span>
      {children}
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="sorting-classes-in-template-literals">
  <h2>
    <a href="#sorting-classes-in-template-literals" name="sorting-classes-in-template-literals" class="pilcrow"></a>
Sorting classes in template literals
  </h2>
</div>
<p>This plugin also enables sorting of classes in tagged template literals.</p>
<p>You can sort classes in template literals using the <code>tailwindFunctions</code> option, which takes a list of function names:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindFunctions&quot;: [&quot;tw&quot;],
}
</code></pre>
<p>With this configuration, any classes in template literals tagged with <code>tw</code> will automatically be sorted:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { View, Text } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'react-native'</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> tw <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'twrnc'</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyScreen</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">View</span> <span class="hljs-attr">style</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{tw</span>`<span class="hljs-attr">bg-white</span> <span class="hljs-attr">p-4</span> <span class="hljs-attr">dark:bg-black</span>`}&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Text</span> <span class="hljs-attr">style</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{tw</span>`<span class="hljs-attr">text-md</span> <span class="hljs-attr">text-black</span> <span class="hljs-attr">dark:text-white</span>`}&gt;</span>Hello World<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">Text</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">View</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<p>This feature can be used with third-party libraries like <code>twrnc</code> or you can create your own tagged template by defining this &quot;identity&quot; function:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> tw = <span class="hljs-function">(<span class="hljs-params">strings, ...values</span>) =&gt;</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">String</span>.raw({ <span class="hljs-attr">raw</span>: strings }, ...values)
</code></pre>
<p>Once added, tag your strings with the function and the plugin will sort them:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> mySortedClasses = tw<span class="hljs-string">`bg-white p-4 dark:bg-black`</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="using-regex-patterns-1">
  <h3>
    <a href="#using-regex-patterns-1" name="using-regex-patterns-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
Using regex patterns
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Like the <code>tailwindAttributes</code> option, the <code>tailwindFunctions</code> option also supports regular expressions to match multiple function names. Patterns should be enclosed in forward slashes. Note that JS regex literals are not supported with Prettier.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="preserving-whitespace">
  <h2>
    <a href="#preserving-whitespace" name="preserving-whitespace" class="pilcrow"></a>
Preserving whitespace
  </h2>
</div>
<p>This plugin automatically removes unnecessary whitespace between classes to ensure consistent formatting. If you prefer to preserve whitespace, you can use the <code>tailwindPreserveWhitespace</code> option:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindPreserveWhitespace&quot;: true,
}
</code></pre>
<p>With this configuration, any whitespace surrounding classes will be preserved:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> clsx <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'clsx'</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyButton</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ isHovering, children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span> <span class="hljs-attr">className</span>=<span class="hljs-string">" rounded  bg-blue-500 px-4  py-2     text-base text-white "</span>&gt;</span>
      {children}
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="preserving-duplicate-classes">
  <h2>
    <a href="#preserving-duplicate-classes" name="preserving-duplicate-classes" class="pilcrow"></a>
Preserving duplicate classes
  </h2>
</div>
<p>This plugin automatically removes duplicate classes from your class lists. However, this can cause issues in some templating languages, like Fluid or Blade, where we can't distinguish between classes and the templating syntax.</p>
<p>If removing duplicate classes is causing issues in your project, you can use the <code>tailwindPreserveDuplicates</code> option to disable this behavior:</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  &quot;tailwindPreserveDuplicates&quot;: true,
}
</code></pre>
<p>With this configuration, anything we perceive as duplicate classes will be preserved:</p>
<pre><code class="html"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">div</span>
  <span class="hljs-attr">class</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"
    {f:if(condition: isCompact, then: 'grid-cols-3', else: 'grid-cols-5')}
    {f:if(condition: isDark, then: 'bg-black/50', else: 'bg-white/50')}
    grid gap-4 p-4
  "</span>
&gt;</span>
<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="compatibility-with-other-prettier-plugins">
  <h2>
    <a href="#compatibility-with-other-prettier-plugins" name="compatibility-with-other-prettier-plugins" class="pilcrow"></a>
Compatibility with other Prettier plugins
  </h2>
</div>
<p>This plugin uses Prettier APIs that can only be used by one plugin at a time, making it incompatible with other Prettier plugins implemented the same way. To solve this we've added explicit per-plugin workarounds that enable compatibility with the following Prettier plugins:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>@ianvs/prettier-plugin-sort-imports</code></li>
<li><code>@prettier/plugin-pug</code></li>
<li><code>@shopify/prettier-plugin-liquid</code></li>
<li><code>@trivago/prettier-plugin-sort-imports</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-astro</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-css-order</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-jsdoc</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-multiline-arrays</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-organize-attributes</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-organize-imports</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-svelte</code></li>
<li><code>prettier-plugin-sort-imports</code></li>
</ul>
<p>One limitation with this approach is that <code>prettier-plugin-tailwindcss</code> <em>must</em> be loaded last.</p>
<pre><code class="json5">// .prettierrc
{
  // ..
  &quot;plugins&quot;: [
    &quot;prettier-plugin-svelte&quot;,
    &quot;prettier-plugin-organize-imports&quot;,
    &quot;prettier-plugin-tailwindcss&quot; // MUST come last
  ]
}
</code></pre>
</div>
  </div>
</body>
</html>
